details.title: Parameter Identification in Degradation Modeling by Reversible-Jump Markov Chain Monte Carlo

authors.affiliation: Energy Dept., Politec. di Milano, Milan

p: Enrico Zio (SM'09) (BS in nuclear engng., Politecnico di Milano, 1991; MSc in mechanical engng., UCLA, 1995; PhD, in nuclear engng., Politecnico di Milano, 1995; PhD, in nuclear engng., MIT, 1998) is the Director of the Graduate School of the Politecnico di Milano, full Professor of Computational Methods for Safety and Risk Analysis. He has served as Vice-Chairman of the European Safety and Reliability Association, ESRA (2000–2005), and as Editor-in-Chief of the International journal Risk, Decision, and Policy (2003-2004). He is currently the Chairman of the Italian Chapter of the IEEE Reliability Society (2001-). He is a member of the editorial board of various international scientific journals on reliability engineering and system safety. He is co-author of two international books, and more than 100 papers in international journals. He serves as referee of several international journals. His research topics are analysis of the reliability, safety, and security of complex systems under stationary, and dynamic operation, particularly by Monte Carlo simulation methods and soft computing techniques.

authors.name: Enrico Zio

authors.affiliation: Energy Dept., Politec. di Milano, Milan

p: Andrea Zoia is a Researcher at the Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique (CEA/Saclay), France. He holds a MSc (2004), and a PhD (2008) in Nuclear Engineering from Politecnico di Milano. His research interests are Monte Carlo methods, and stochastic transport processes. He is author or co-author of about 15 papers in international journals.

authors.name: Andrea Zoia

details.abstract: In this work, the reversible-jump Markov chain Monte Carlo technique is applied for identifying the parameters governing stochastic processes of component degradation. Two case studies are examined concerning the evolution of deteriorating systems whose parameters undergo step changes in time. The method turns out to be capable of identifying the instances of change in behavior, and of estimating the parameter values. A Bayesian updating strategy is proposed to refine the parameter estimates as new data are made available.

references.title:
Equations of state calculation
by fast computing machines

context.text: Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms [10]–[13] offer an effective way for addressing parameter identification, and more generally the issue of Bayesian posterior inference.
In this work, the Metropolis-Hastings MCMC algorithm is considered [10] [11].
[10]; the generalization to non-symmetric kinetics is due to Hastings [11].

The initial \$m\$ values of the chain (the so-called burn-in period) are discarded, and the remaining \$n-m\$ values, under mild assumptions on the assigned kinetics \$K(\cdot\vert\cdot)\$ [10] [11] [14], [16]–[20] [22] approximately follow the target distribution \$\pi(\theta\vert x)\$.
The approximation is due to the fact that the values \$\theta^{j}\$ of the chain are by definition correlated [10] [11].

Let us continue considering the component deteriorating according to the Paris-Erdogan fatigue crack growth model, and make two simplifications: i) the dataset has a single changepoint \$k=1\$ so that the parameter space has fixed dimensionality, and the standard Metropolis-Hastings MCMC algorithm [10] [11] can be applied; and ii) the parameter \$\mu\$ is fixed, and known.

references.title:
Monte Carlo sampling methods
using Markov Chains and their applications

context.text: Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms [10]–[11][13] offer an effective way for addressing parameter identification, and more generally the issue of Bayesian posterior inference.
In this work, the Metropolis-Hastings MCMC algorithm is considered [10] [11].
This was indeed the choice in the original algorithm by Metropolis et al. [10]; the generalization to non-symmetric kinetics is due to Hastings [11].

The initial \$m\$ values of the chain (the so-called burn-in period) are discarded, and the remaining \$n-m\$ values, under mild assumptions on the assigned kinetics \$K(\cdot\vert\cdot)\$ [10] [11] [14], [16]–[20] [22] approximately follow the target distribution \$\pi(\theta\vert x)\$.
The approximation is due to the fact that the values \$\theta^{j}\$ of the chain are by definition correlated [10] [11].

Let us continue considering the component deteriorating according to the Paris-Erdogan fatigue crack growth model, and make two simplifications: i) the dataset has a single changepoint \$k=1\$ so that the parameter space has fixed dimensionality, and the standard Metropolis-Hastings MCMC algorithm [10] [11] can be applied; and ii) the parameter \$\mu\$ is fixed, and known.

references.text: W. K. Hastings, "Monte Carlo sampling methods using Markov Chains and their applications", Biometrika, vol. 57, pp. 97-109, 1970.

links.abstract: We make an analogy between images and statistical mechanics systems. Pixel gray levels and the presence and orientation of edges are viewed as states of atoms or molecules in a lattice-like physical system. The assignment of an energy function in the physical system determines its Gibbs distribution. Because of the Gibbs distribution, Markov random field (MRF) equivalence, this assignment also determines an MRF image model. The energy function is a more convenient and natural mechanism for embod...

references.text: S. Geman, D. Geman, "Stochastic relaxation Gibbs distributions and the Bayesian restoration of images", IEEE Trans. Pattern Anal. and Machine Intell., vol. 6, pp. 721-741, 1984.

references.title: Markov Chain Monte Carlo in Practice

context.text: Detailed reviews on the subjects may be found e.g. in [14]–[20].

One can then resort to Monte Carlo simulation [21] which amounts to sampling \$n\$ values \$\theta_{1},\theta_{2},\ldots,\theta_{n}\$ from \$\pi(\theta)\$ and then estimating the expectation \$E[f(\theta)]\$ as This gives an unbiased estimate, with a standard deviation of order \$\sqrt{n}\$ [14] [16] [20] [21].
This approach is based on the construction of a Markov chain, whose stationary distribution is the target function \$\pi(\theta)\$ [14] [20].

If the Markov chain is run long enough, the distribution of the generated values \$\theta_{i}\vert x\$ becomes stationary, and approaches \$\pi(\theta\vert x)\$ independently of the starting point of the chain [14] [20].

This is undoubtedly a major benefit of the algorithm because, for Bayesian inference problems, the computation of the normalization factor is usually extremely cumbersome, and must be performed by numerical integration [14] [16] [20].

The initial \$m\$ values of the chain (the so-called burn-in period) are discarded, and the remaining \$n-m\$ values, under mild assumptions on the assigned kinetics \$K(\cdot\vert\cdot)\$ [10] [11] [14], [16]–[20] [22] approximately follow the target distribution \$\pi(\theta\vert x)\$.
In the framework of the use of MCMC for Bayesian inference, one of the most contentious issues is choosing whether to run one long chain, or several short chains in parallel [14] [16].

references.text: W. R. Gilks, S. Richardson, D. J. Spiegelhalter, Markov Chain Monte Carlo in Practice, 1996, Chapman and Hall.

references.title: Monte Carlo Statistical Methods

context.text: Detailed reviews on the subjects may be found e.g. in [14]–[15][20].

references.text: G. Casella, C. P. Robert, Monte Carlo Statistical Methods, 2005, Springer.

references.title:
Markov chain Monte Carlo method
and its application

context.text: Detailed reviews on the subjects may be found e.g. in [14]–[16][20].

One can then resort to Monte Carlo simulation [21] which amounts to sampling \$n\$ values \$\theta_{1},\theta_{2},\ldots,\theta_{n}\$ from \$\pi(\theta)\$ and then estimating the expectation \$E[f(\theta)]\$ as This gives an unbiased estimate, with a standard deviation of order \$\sqrt{n}\$ [14] [16] [20] [21].

While MCMC algorithms are used in many fields of science (such as statistical mechanics, and computer science), their most widespread application is in Bayesian statistical inference [16], [22]–[24] in which case the target distribution is the posterior distribution \$\pi(\theta\vert x)\$ given a set of measures \$x\$.

This is undoubtedly a major benefit of the algorithm because, for Bayesian inference problems, the computation of the normalization factor is usually extremely cumbersome, and must be performed by numerical integration [14] [16] [20].

The initial \$m\$ values of the chain (the so-called burn-in period) are discarded, and the remaining \$n-m\$ values, under mild assumptions on the assigned kinetics \$K(\cdot\vert\cdot)\$ [10] [11] [14], [16]–[20] [22] approximately follow the target distribution \$\pi(\theta\vert x)\$.
Hence, in practice, one resorts to empirical numerical methods for detecting convergence of the generated chain [16].
In the framework of the use of MCMC for Bayesian inference, one of the most contentious issues is choosing whether to run one long chain, or several short chains in parallel [14] [16].
This latter approach could also be useful to monitor the mixing properties of the generated sequence by comparing the different outputs of the chains [16].

references.text: S. P. Brooks, "Markov chain Monte Carlo method and its application", The Statistician, vol. 47, pp. 69-100, 1998.

references.title:
General state space Markov
chains and MCMC algorithms

context.text: Detailed reviews on the subjects may be found e.g. in [14]–[20].

Consider a (possibly not normalized) probability density function \$\pi(\theta)\$ on some space \$\Omega\$ and the expectation of a function \$f(\theta)\$ When \$\Omega\$ is high-dimensional, and/or \$\pi(\theta)\$ is a complicated function, the computation of \$E[f(\theta)]\$ by direct integration (either analytic or numerical) is in general infeasible [20].

One can then resort to Monte Carlo simulation [21] which amounts to sampling \$n\$ values \$\theta_{1},\theta_{2},\ldots,\theta_{n}\$ from \$\pi(\theta)\$ and then estimating the expectation \$E[f(\theta)]\$ as This gives an unbiased estimate, with a standard deviation of order \$\sqrt{n}\$ [14] [16] [20] [21].
This approach is based on the construction of a Markov chain, whose stationary distribution is the target function \$\pi(\theta)\$ [14] [20].

If the Markov chain is run long enough, the distribution of the generated values \$\theta_{i}\vert x\$ becomes stationary, and approaches \$\pi(\theta\vert x)\$ independently of the starting point of the chain [14] [20].

This is undoubtedly a major benefit of the algorithm because, for Bayesian inference problems, the computation of the normalization factor is usually extremely cumbersome, and must be performed by numerical integration [14] [16] [20].

The initial \$m\$ values of the chain (the so-called burn-in period) are discarded, and the remaining \$n-m\$ values, under mild assumptions on the assigned kinetics \$K(\cdot\vert\cdot)\$ [10] [11] [14], [16]–[20] [22] approximately follow the target distribution \$\pi(\theta\vert x)\$.

references.text: G. O. Roberts, J. S. Rosenthal, "General state space Markov chains and MCMC algorithms", Probability Surveys, vol. 1, pp. 20-71, 2004.

references.title:
Reversible jump Markov chain
Monte Carlo computation and Bayesian model determination

context.text: This problem has been extensively studied in the framework of Bayesian posterior analysis (see e.g. [25]–[26][31] and references therein).

An efficient solution to perform Bayesian analysis in the context of an unknown number of changepoints has been suggested by Green in a seminal paper [26] and is known as the reversible-jump MCMC algorithm.

For completeness, in the following, a short review is provided of the algorithm introduced in [26] to perform Bayesian analysis of experimental data when the number of possible changepoints in the dataset is itself unknown, so that the dimension of the parameter space is variable.
These last two moves involve a change in the dimension of the parameter space, so that the standard MCMC theory can not be applied [26].

Following [26] \$\eta_{k}\$ is set equal to \$\chi_{k}\$ when \$k\neq 0\$ and the probabilities of a birth, or death event are chosen to be in the form \$b_{k}=c\min\{1,p(k+1)/p(k)\}\$ and \$d_{k}=c\min\{1,p(k-1)/p(k)\}\$ respectively.

The acceptance probability is 

•
The birth move is based on the dimension-matching criterion introduced in [26] which enables us to switch from a parameter space of dimension \$k\$ to another space of dimension \$k+1\$.

An existing location \$s_{i}\$ is selected at random to be removed; the new parameter on the interval is then determined by reversing the birth move so that the dimension-matching criterion between the \$k\rightarrow k-1\$ and \$k \rightarrow k+1\$ moves is satisfied [26]: The acceptance probability \$\alpha_{d}\$ has the same form as the acceptance probability \$\alpha_{b}\$ for the birth move, with the due changes in the variables labels [26] [29] [31].
The birth move is based on the dimension-matching criterion introduced in [26] which enables us to switch from a parameter space of dimension \$k\$ to another space of dimension \$k+1\$.

An existing location \$s_{i}\$ is selected at random to be removed; the new parameter on the interval is then determined by reversing the birth move so that the dimension-matching criterion between the \$k\rightarrow k-1\$ and \$k \rightarrow k+1\$ moves is satisfied [26]: The acceptance probability \$\alpha_{d}\$ has the same form as the acceptance probability \$\alpha_{b}\$ for the birth move, with the due changes in the variables labels [26] [29] [31].

Supposing that the underlying stochastic model for the failure times of the component is a time-inhomogeneous Poisson process [26] [31], [34]–[36] the log-likelihood function is where \$\lambda\$ plays the role of the parameter \$\theta\$ in the previous notation, \$s_{0}=0\$ and \$s_{k+1}=T\$ is the final failure time in the dataset.

references.text: P. J. Green, "Reversible jump Markov chain Monte Carlo computation and Bayesian model determination", Biometrika, vol. 82, pp. 711-732, 1995.

links.abstract: This paper addresses the problem of change point detection in signals corrupted by multiplicative noise. Multiplicative noise has been observed in many signal processing applications. These applications include image processing (speckle) or communication systems (fading channels). This paper focuses on edge detection in synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images contaminated by multiplicative speckle noise. However, the proposed approach could also be used for the segmentation of any multiplicative n...

references.text: J.-Y. Tourneret, M. Coulon, M. Doisy, "Least square estimation of multiple changepoints contaminated by multiplicative noise using MCMC", IEEE Workshop on Higher-Order Statistics, pp. 148-152, 1999.

links.abstract: In this paper, we investigate some techniques for reliability prediction and assessment of fielded software. We first review how several existing software reliability growth models based on non-homogeneous Poisson processes (NHPPs) can be readily derived based on a unified theory for NHPP models. Furthermore, based on the unified theory, we can incorporate the concept of multiple change-points into software reliability modeling. Some models are proposed and discussed under both ideal and imperfe...

references.text: C.-Y. Huang, C.-T. Lin, "Reliability prediction and assessment of fielded software based on multiple change-point models", Proceedings of PRDC 05, pp. 379-386, 2005.
